milestones.title: Async Endpoints & Database Integration
milestones.description: Connect FastAPI to PostgreSQL with async for maximum performance.
milestones.lesson:
# Async Endpoints & Database Integration

## async def vs def in FastAPI
```python
# SYNC — runs in a thread pool (fine for CPU-bound work)
@app.get("/sync")
def sync_endpoint():
    return {"mode": "sync"}

# ASYNC — runs on the event loop (best for I/O: DB, HTTP, files)
@app.get("/async")
async def async_endpoint():
    return {"mode": "async"}
```

**Rule of thumb:**
- Use `async def` when calling async libraries (asyncpg, aiohttp, aiofiles)
- Use `def` when calling sync libraries (psycopg2, requests)
- NEVER use `time.sleep()` in async endpoints — use `await asyncio.sleep()`

## Async SQLAlchemy Setup
```python
from sqlalchemy.ext.asyncio import create_async_engine, async_sessionmaker, AsyncSession

# Note: asyncpg driver (not psycopg2)
DATABASE_URL = "postgresql+asyncpg://postgres:pass@localhost:5432/myapp"

async_engine = create_async_engine(DATABASE_URL)
AsyncSessionLocal = async_sessionmaker(async_engine, class_=AsyncSession)

async def get_async_db():
    async with AsyncSessionLocal() as session:
        yield session
```

## Async CRUD
```python
from sqlalchemy import select

@app.get("/users")
async def list_users(db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_async_db)):
    result = await db.execute(select(User))
    users = result.scalars().all()
    return users

@app.post("/users")
async def create_user(data: UserCreate, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_async_db)):
    user = User(**data.model_dump())
    db.add(user)
    await db.commit()
    await db.refresh(user)
    return user
```

## Concurrent Queries
```python
import asyncio

@app.get("/dashboard")
async def dashboard(db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_async_db)):
    # Run 3 queries concurrently — faster than sequential!
    users_q = db.execute(select(func.count(User.id)))
    posts_q = db.execute(select(func.count(Post.id)))
    recent_q = db.execute(select(Post).order_by(Post.created_at.desc()).limit(5))

    user_count, post_count, recent = await asyncio.gather(
        users_q, posts_q, recent_q
    )

    return {
        "users": user_count.scalar(),
        "posts": post_count.scalar(),
        "recent": recent.scalars().all(),
    }
```

## Key Takeaway
Async endpoints + async SQLAlchemy = FastAPI at full speed. Use `asyncpg` as your driver, `AsyncSession` for database access, and `asyncio.gather` when you have independent queries. This is the Siraaj production setup.
steps: Convert a sync FastAPI app to use async endpoints
Set up async_engine with asyncpg driver
Create an async get_db dependency using AsyncSession
Use asyncio.gather to run concurrent database queries
Compare response times between sync and async

milestones.title: Middleware, Error Handling & CORS
milestones.description: Add cross-cutting concerns: logging, error handling, and CORS for frontend integration.
milestones.lesson:
# Middleware, Error Handling & CORS

## Middleware — Code That Runs on Every Request
```python
import time
from fastapi import Request

@app.middleware("http")
async def add_timing(request: Request, call_next):
    start = time.time()
    response = await call_next(request)
    duration = time.time() - start
    response.headers["X-Response-Time"] = f"{duration:.4f}s"
    print(f"{request.method} {request.url.path} - {duration:.4f}s")
    return response
```

## Exception Handlers
```python
from fastapi import HTTPException
from fastapi.responses import JSONResponse

# Built-in HTTPException
@app.get("/users/{user_id}")
async def get_user(user_id: int):
    user = await find_user(user_id)
    if not user:
        raise HTTPException(status_code=404, detail="User not found")
    return user

# Custom Exception Class
class AppException(Exception):
    def __init__(self, code: str, message: str, status_code: int = 400):
        self.code = code
        self.message = message
        self.status_code = status_code

@app.exception_handler(AppException)
async def app_exception_handler(request: Request, exc: AppException):
    return JSONResponse(
        status_code=exc.status_code,
        content={
            "error": {
                "code": exc.code,
                "message": exc.message,
            }
        },
    )

# Usage in endpoints:
raise AppException(code="USER_NOT_FOUND", message="No user with that ID", status_code=404)
```

## CORS — Allow Frontend to Call Your API
```python
from fastapi.middleware.cors import CORSMiddleware

app.add_middleware(
    CORSMiddleware,
    allow_origins=["http://localhost:3000", "https://app.siraaj.ai"],
    allow_credentials=True,
    allow_methods=["*"],
    allow_headers=["*"],
)
```

Without CORS middleware, your browser will BLOCK requests from your React frontend to your FastAPI backend (different ports = different origins).

## Request Lifecycle
```
Client Request
  → CORS Middleware (check origin)
  → Custom Middleware (timing, logging)
  → Route Handler (your endpoint)
  → Exception Handler (if error)
  → Response back to client
```

## Key Takeaway
Middleware = reusable logic for every request. Exception handlers = consistent error responses. CORS = allow your frontend to talk to your backend. All three are configured in every Siraaj API.
steps: Add a request timing middleware that logs method + path + duration
Create a custom AppException class with code, message, status_code
Configure CORSMiddleware for your frontend origin
Test error responses with /docs and verify JSON format

milestones.title: Building a Complete CRUD API (Capstone)
milestones.description: Put everything together — build a production-structured API from scratch.
milestones.lesson:
# Building a Complete CRUD API (Capstone)

## Project Structure
```
task_api/
├── main.py              # FastAPI app, middleware, startup
├── config.py            # Settings via Pydantic
├── database.py          # Engine, session, Base
├── models/
│   ├── user.py          # User SQLAlchemy model
│   └── task.py          # Task SQLAlchemy model
├── schemas/
│   ├── user.py          # UserCreate, UserResponse
│   └── task.py          # TaskCreate, TaskUpdate, TaskResponse
├── crud/
│   ├── user.py          # User CRUD operations
│   └── task.py          # Task CRUD operations
├── routers/
│   ├── users.py         # User endpoints
│   └── tasks.py         # Task endpoints
├── dependencies.py      # get_db, get_current_user
└── exceptions.py        # Custom exceptions + handlers
```

## Configuration with Pydantic Settings
```python
# config.py
from pydantic_settings import BaseSettings

class Settings(BaseSettings):
    database_url: str = "postgresql+asyncpg://postgres:pass@localhost/taskapi"
    secret_key: str = "dev-secret"
    debug: bool = True

    model_config = ConfigDict(env_file=".env")

settings = Settings()
```

## APIRouter — Grouping Endpoints
```python
# routers/users.py
from fastapi import APIRouter, Depends

router = APIRouter(prefix="/users", tags=["Users"])

@router.get("/")
async def list_users(db = Depends(get_db)):
    ...

@router.post("/", status_code=201)
async def create_user(data: UserCreate, db = Depends(get_db)):
    ...

# main.py
from routers import users, tasks

app.include_router(users.router, prefix="/api")
app.include_router(tasks.router, prefix="/api")
# Endpoints: /api/users, /api/tasks
```

## The Full Flow: Request to Response
```
1. Client sends POST /api/tasks {"title": "Learn FastAPI"}
2. CORSMiddleware checks origin -> OK
3. Logging middleware starts timer
4. FastAPI matches route -> routers/tasks.py create_task()
5. Depends(get_db) yields database session
6. Depends(get_current_user) validates auth token
7. Pydantic validates TaskCreate schema
8. crud/task.py creates the task in DB
9. Response serialized through TaskResponse schema
10. Logging middleware logs: POST /api/tasks 201 0.045s
```

## Tracing a Siraaj Endpoint
To understand a real production codebase, trace one endpoint:
```
1. Find the route in routers/ (e.g., routers/feedback.py)
2. See what dependencies it uses (get_db, get_current_user)
3. Follow to the CRUD function (crud/feedback.py)
4. See the SQLAlchemy model (models/feedback.py)
5. Check the Pydantic schemas (schemas/feedback.py)
```

## Key Takeaway
A production API is just these pieces organized well: routers (endpoints) -> schemas (validation) -> crud (DB operations) -> models (table definitions). Every Siraaj endpoint follows this exact pattern. Build one yourself and you can read any endpoint in the codebase.

Create Pydantic schemas: TaskCreate, TaskUpdate, TaskResponse

Add pagination, filtering by status, and ordering
Wire everything in main.py with middleware and CORS
